105 C.M.R. 410.190.proposition: Pursuant to the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, a landlord is required to provide adequate hot water to tenants, meeting the temperature and availability requirements set forth in the regulation.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The prolonged lack of hot water in a residence is a serious Sanitary Code violation and a condition affecting health and safety.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Adequate and continuous hot water is an essential service and a basic requirement of a habitable residential dwelling under Massachusetts law.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) clearly accepts that there is, and should be, a legally enforceable minimum standard of habitability for Massachusetts dwellings, grounded in the State Sanitary Code. That Code, as described here, includes hot water as a minimum standard, so adequate and continuous hot water falls within the "minimum standards of fitness" and thus within the basic requirements of a habitable dwelling. However, the excerpt does not single out hot water explicitly; it instead generally incorporates all Code requirements into the landlord’s implied obligations, so the support is by necessary implication, not express language.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code, which has the force of law… fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit… which does not comply’ with its provisions… As the first step in the removal of the roadblock… I would… hold… that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord… an obligation to comply with those minimum standards.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts common law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, which protects a tenant from substantial interference by the landlord with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes “quiet enjoyment” as a well-established concept in landlord-tenant law, defines it as freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the premises, and states that every tenancy carries an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right. It also interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” clause against this common-law background, confirming that the statutory protection covers substantial interferences by the landlord with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. This directly supports the proposition stated.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: A landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where his acts or omissions, after notice, substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including by allowing serious Sanitary Code violations to persist.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where his acts or omissions, after notice, substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment (here, intolerable noise from a lounge the landlord introduced and could control). The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling and rejects any nonfeasance/malfeasance distinction where the landlord creates a situation and fails to abate it after complaints. However, the opinion does not specifically discuss Sanitary Code violations; that portion of the proposition is an extrapolation, not directly addressed in this case.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where his acts or omissions, after notice, substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including by allowing serious Sanitary Code violations to persist.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and describes the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants against serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, focusing on what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done. It further holds that the landlord may be liable where, after notice, it fails to take available measures to address conditions (here, pervasive criminal activity in common areas) that seriously interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises. While the case involves security and drug activity rather than classic Sanitary Code conditions, its articulation of liability for omissions after notice that substantially impair use and enjoyment tracks the proposition’s rule and is frequently cited for that standard in the Sanitary Code context.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that the landlord’s failure to correct violations of the State Sanitary Code after notice may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses when a landlord’s conduct constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and expressly notes that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises has frequently been deemed to violate the quiet enjoyment statute. It cites prior Massachusetts cases (including sanitary/habitability conditions) as examples of such breaches. Thus, while the case’s main holding concerns lead paint and negligence, its reasoning affirms that failure to correct code-type defects after notice can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–77 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that the landlord’s failure to correct violations of the State Sanitary Code after notice may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion involves a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the court does not discuss the legal standard for such a breach or link it specifically to State Sanitary Code violations and notice. The decision focuses on the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy, and mentions the quiet enjoyment claim only in passing, without articulating or reaffirming the proposition that failure to correct Sanitary Code violations after notice may constitute a breach. Therefore, it does not provide direct authority for the stated proposition.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment has been substantial, not trivial or technical, in that Plaintiff has been deprived of hot water for approximately three weeks, has been unable to bathe normally in her home, has had to travel to a gym and to her mother’s house for bathing, and has had to boil water for everyday tasks.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does involve loss of heat and hot water and recognizes those conditions as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability. However, it does not discuss the specific factual scenario in the proposition (three weeks with no hot water, traveling to a gym/mother’s house to bathe, boiling water, or the quiet enjoyment standard). The case is focused on rent abatement and strict liability for Sanitary Code violations, not on characterizing the degree of interference with quiet enjoyment in the detailed way described in the proposition.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–89 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes G.L. c. 186, § 14 and describes the landlord’s liability as including “actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” This language matches the proposition that a plaintiff is entitled to recover actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”
